title: 111_s3238
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. Congress finds that the tragic deaths on September 11, 2001, have forever changed the nation. The heroic actions of officers, emergency workers, and employees who responded to the attacks at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon are recognized. The passengers and crew of United Airlines Flight 93 are also acknowledged for their bravery in preventing further casualties. The casualties of Pentagon employees and the passengers and crew of United Airlines Flight 93 took heroic action to prevent further harm during the September 11, 2001 attacks. Their sacrifice deserves recognition with an appropriate medal. SEC. 3. FALLEN HEROES OF 9/11 CONGRESSIONAL MEDALS. The President is authorized to award a "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal" to individuals and organizations in recognition of their sacrifice and honor their deaths on and after September 11, 2001. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike 3 designs of medals for this purpose. The Secretary will determine suitable emblems, devices, and inscriptions for medals honoring those who lost their lives in the 9/11 attacks at the World Trade Center, Flight 93, and the Pentagon. Consultation with the Secretary of Defense and other relevant parties will precede the final design decision. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense and other relevant parties, will determine the design and content of silver and gold medals to honor individuals who died as a direct result of the 9/11 terrorist attacks. Eligibility for the medal will be determined by the Secretary in consultation with other government officials. SEC. 4. DUPLICATE MEDALS.

The Secretary will create bronze duplicates of medals for individuals who responded to the 9/11 attacks and perished, to be displayed at their duty stations. Recipients include officers, emergency workers, and government employees.

SEC. 5. ESTABLISHMENT OF LISTS OF RECIPIENTS. Before the end of the 120-day period after the enactment of this Act, the Secretary will establish lists of eligible individuals to receive a medal for their actions during the period of September 11, 2001, to the present, as well as a list of recipients eligible for duplicate medals. The Secretary will consult various organizations to make these determinations, and the lists created will be final. The Secretary will establish lists of eligible individuals to receive a medal for their actions from September 11, 2001, onwards, in consultation with organizations like the Armed Forces Medical Examiners System. The lists are final and not subject to judicial review. If new individuals become eligible for a medal, the Secretary will promptly add their names to the appropriate list. The Secretary may sell duplicate bronze medals to the public to cover costs. The medals struck under this Act are considered national medals.
